p: The global threat of contagious infectious diseases, particularly tuberculosis (TB), has long concerned authorities in charge of public health policies. Most data and all predictions concerning global epidemiology of TB are based on “ real-life” analysis (surveys and national surveillance programs) conducted by the World Health Organization (WHO) [ 1, 2]. The incidence of TB is slowly declining but remains a significant issue worldwide (ranked as the ninth leading cause of death worldwide and the leading cause of a single infectious agent [ 3, 4]), especially in most middle-income and emerging-economy countries.
